unnormalised: Alright folks, settle down, settle down! Let’s talk about probability and statistics. Now, I know what you're thinking: "Maths? Ugh, prepone my dentist appointment!" But trust me, this isn't your standard textbook snooze-fest. We’re gonna give it a desi tadka, a little spice, to make it more palatable. After all, even your humble chaiwala uses probability and statistics, even if he doesn’t realize it!

unnormalised: Think about it. Sharmaji's chai stall is legendary, right? But why? Is it just his winning smile? (Okay, maybe a little). But mostly, he's unconsciously running statistical analyses all day long. He knows that on Mondays, 70% of his customers want extra sugar. Tuesdays? Ginger chai is the clear favourite, with 60% opting for it. He’s collecting data, baby! He’s building a model, predicting future chai demand! He’s practically a data scientist in disguise! His error rate might be, let’s say, +/- 5%, but hey, for chai, that's acceptable. I mean, someone is always going to say "bhaiya, thoda aur cheeni"

unnormalised: And what about the probability of getting caught in the monsoon rains without an umbrella in Mumbai? Close to 100%, isn't it? Unless you are a genius weather forecaster or willing to accept this statistical inevitability. It's basically the law of averages, but with a guaranteed soaking. Someone should run the data on this, 99.99% chance of getting drenched and stuck in traffic for at least 2 hrs. The real question is: what's the probability of finding an auto-rickshaw willing to take you home in that downpour? That's a problem for another day!

unnormalised: Now, let's talk about cricket. Specifically, the odds of India winning the World Cup. What are the chances? Let’s conservatively say 65%, because, well, optimism is our national sport. But even that's based on some heavy-duty stats, isn't it? The bowlers' average economy rate, Virat's batting average, the pitch conditions in Ahmedabad – it's all data! And those commentators? They're practically statistical wizards, throwing around numbers like "a 75% chance of winning if they take 3 wickets in the next 5 overs." Suddenly the guy who never went to statistic classes knows all the things.

unnormalised: Consider the lottery. The probability of winning the jackpot? Well, let’s just say it's roughly the same as the probability of finding a parking spot in Chandni Chowk on Diwali (less than 0.000000001%). But still, we buy those tickets, don't we? Why? Because even with those dismal odds, there's still a chance, however slim. It's that glimmer of hope, that sliver of statistical possibility, that keeps us going. Plus you've gotta give it to Raju, the lottery seller at the corner of the street. He has incredible consistency of selling.

unnormalised: So, the next time you're sipping your chai, getting stuck in traffic, or watching cricket, remember: probability and statistics are all around us. They're the invisible forces shaping our daily lives, from the mundane to the miraculous. And who knows, maybe learning a little bit about them can help you predict the future… or at least improve your chances of finding that elusive auto-rickshaw on a rainy day. Oh and don't forget the important stuff. Take the probability that tomorrow's class will be cancelled if Prof. Sharma has a cold.
